Speaker: stevie
Dialogue: I got...I got....I got....  ....the wind knocked out of me.

Speaker: stevie
Dialogue: Human skull.

Speaker: stevie
Dialogue: No way, buttwipe. I found it. It's mine.

Speaker: stevie
Dialogue: Anyways, there's bones all over the place down here.

Speaker: fire captain
Dialogue: This is Captain Miles Cooles...we've got a rescue situation in progress...

Speaker: bronschweig
Dialogue: Keep those people back. Get them out of here.

Speaker: fire captain
Dialogue: I sent four men down after the boy. They're not responding.

Speaker: fire captain
Dialogue: What about my men?

Speaker: fbi agent
Dialogue: We've evacuated the building and been through it bottom to top. No trace of an explosive device or anything resembling one.

Speaker: fbi agent
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Mulder -- it's me --

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: I'm on the roof.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: No. I haven't.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: I've just climbed twelve floors. I'm hot and thirsty and I'm wondering, to be honest, what I'm doing here.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: I know that. But the threat was called in for the Federal Building across the street.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Mulder... when a terrorist bomb threat is called in, the logical purpose of providing this information is to allow us to find the bomb. The rational object of terrorism is to promote terror. If you'd study model behavioral pattern in virtually every case where a threat has turned up an explosive device. If we don't act in accordance with that data -- if you ignore it as we have done -- the chances are great that if here actually is a bomb we might not find it. Lives could be lost --

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Mulder...?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: What happened to playing a hunch?

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Jesus, Mulder...

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: The element of surprise, Scully. Random acts of unpredictability. If we fail to anticipate the unforeseen or expect the unexpected in a universe of infinite possibilities, we find ourselves at the mercy of anyone or anything that cannot be programmed, categorized or easily referenced...

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: What are we doing up here? It's hotter than hell.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: I know you're bored in this assignment, but unconventional thinking is only going to get you into trouble now.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: How's that?

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: You've got to quit looking for what isn't there. They've closed the X-Files. There's procedure to be followed here. Protocol.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: What do you say we call in a bomb threat for Houston. I think it's free beer night at the Astrodome.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Now what?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: It's locked?

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: So much for anticipating the unforeseen...

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Had you.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: No you didn't.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Oh yeah. Had you big time.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: I saw your face, Mulder. There was a moment of panic.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Panic? Have you ever seen me panic, Scully?

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: I just did. You're buying.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Alright... what'll it be: Coke, Pepsi? A saline IV?

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Something sweet.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Oh, come on.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Scully...

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Where are you, Mulder?

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Is that you pounding?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Scully, get somebody to open this door.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Scully -- listen to me. It's in the coke machine. You've got about fourteen minutes to get this building evacuated.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: C'mon. Open the door.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Mulder? Tell me this is a joke.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: ...thirteen fifty six...

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: I need this building evacuated and cleared out in ten minutes! I need you to get on the phone and tell the fire department to block off the city center in one mile radius around the building --

Speaker: security guard
Dialogue: In ten minutes.....?!

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: DON'T THINK! JUST PICK UP THE PHONE AND MAKE IT HAPPEN!

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: This is Special Agent Dana Scully. I need to speak to S.A.C. Michaud. He's got the wrong building --

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Mulder found it in a vending machine. He's locked in with it.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Scully?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Tell me this is just soda pop in those canisters.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Somebody's got to stay with you --

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Can you defuse it?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: You've got about four minutes to find out if you're wrong.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Let's go, Mulder.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: What are you doing?  Mulder --

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Something's wrong.

Speaker: windbreakered agent
Dialogue: What's he doing?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Something's not right...

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: -- Mulder! Get in the car!

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: There's no time!

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Next time you're buying.

Speaker: cassidy
Dialogue: ...for the catastrophic destruction of public property and the loss of life due to terrorist activities...

Speaker: cassidy
Dialogue: Many details are still unclear; some agents' reports have not been filed, or have come in sketchy, without a satisfactory accounting of the events that led to the destruction in Dallas. But we're under some pressure to give an accurate picture of what happened to the Attorney General, so she can issue a public statement.

Speaker: cassidy
Dialogue: We now know that five people died in the explosion. Special Agent in Charge Darius Michaud who was trying to defuse the bomb that had been hidden in a vending machine. Three firemen from Dallas, and a young boy.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Excuse me -- the firemen and the boy -- they were in the building?

Speaker: cassidy
Dialogue: Agent Mulder, since you weren't able to be on time for this hearing, I'm going to ask you to step outside so that we can get Agent Scully's version of the facts. So that she won't have to be paid the same disrespect.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: We were told the building was clear.

Speaker: cassidy
Dialogue: You'll get your turn, Agent Mulder. Please step out.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: It does say there in your paperwork that we were the ones who found the bomb...

Speaker: cassidy
Dialogue: Thank you, Agent Mulder. We'll call you in shortly.

Speaker: skinner
Dialogue: Sit down, they're still talking to Agent Scully.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: About what?

Speaker: skinner
Dialogue: -- They're asking her for a narrative. They want to know why she was in the wrong building.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: She was with me.

Speaker: skinner
Dialogue: You don't see what's going on here, do you?  There's four hundred million dollars in damage to the city of Dallas. Lives have been lost. No suspects have been named. So the story being shaped is this could have been prevented. That the FBI didn't do its job.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: And they want to blame us?

Speaker: skinner
Dialogue: Agent Mulder -- we both know that if you and Agent Scully hadn't taken the initiative to search the adjacent building, you could have multiplied the fatalities by a hundred --

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: But it's not the lives we saved. It's the lives we didn't.

Speaker: skinner
Dialogue: -- if it looks bad, it's bad for the FBI --

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: -- if they want someone to blame, they can blame me. Agent Scully doesn't deserve this.

Speaker: skinner
Dialogue: She's in there right now saying the same thing about you.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: I breached protocol. I broke contact with the S.A.C. I ignored a primary tactical rule and left him alone with the device.

Speaker: skinner
Dialogue: Agent Scully says it was she who ordered you out of the building. That you wanted to go back.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: They're asking for you, Sir.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Whatever you told them in there, you don't have to protect me.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: All I told them was the truth.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: They're trying to divide us on this, Scully. We can't let them.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: They have divided us, Mulder. They're splitting us up.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: What? What are you talking about?

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: I meet with the OPR day after tomorrow for remediation and reassignment...

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: I think you must have an idea. They cited a history of problems relating

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: They were the ones that put us together.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Because they wanted me to invalidate your work, your investigations into the paranormal. But I think this goes deeper than that.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: This isn't about you, Scully. They're doing this to me.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: They're not doing this, Mulder.  I left behind a career in medicine because I thought I might make a difference at the FBI. When they recruited me they told me women made up nine percent of the bureau. I felt this was not an impediment, but an opportunity to distinguish myself. But it hasn't turned out that way. And now, if I were to be transferred to Omaha, or Wichita or some field office where I'm sure I could rise, it just doesn't hold the interest for me it once did. Not after what I've seen and done.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: You're... quitting?

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: There's really no reason left for me to stay anymore.  Maybe you should ask yourself if your heart's still in it, too.

Speaker: skinner
Dialogue: Agent Mulder. You're up.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: I'm sorry. Good luck.

Speaker: barmaid
Dialogue: I'd say this about exceeds your minimum daily requirement.

Speaker: barmaid
Dialogue: Gotta train for this kind of heavy lifting.

Speaker: barmaid
Dialogue: Poopy day?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Yup.

Speaker: barmaid
Dialogue: A woman?  Work.

Speaker: barmaid
Dialogue: What do you do?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: What do I do.  I'm a key figure in an ongoing government charade. An annoyance to my superiors. A joke among my peers. "Spooky," they call me. Spooky Mulder. Whose sister was abducted by aliens when he was a kid. Who now chases little green men with a badge and a gun, shouting to the heavens and anyone who'll listen that the fix is in. That our government's hip to the truth and a part of the conspiracy. That the sky is falling and when it hits it's gonna be the shitstorm of all time.

Speaker: barmaid
Dialogue: I think that about does it, Spooky.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Does what?

Speaker: barmaid
Dialogue: Why don't you go home to the old lady --

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Sorry. Don't have one.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: Bet the Bureau's accusing you of the same thing in Dallas.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: How's that?

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: Standing around holding your yank while bombs are exploding.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Do I know you?

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: No. I've been watching your career for a good while. Back when you were just a promising young agent -- before that.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: You follow me out here for a reason?

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: Yeah, I did.

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: My name's Kurtzweil. Dr. Alvin Kurtzweil.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: I know the name. Why?

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: Old friend of your father's.

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: Back at the Department of State. We were what you might call fellow travelers, but his disenchantment outlasted mine.  I never believed in the Project.

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: Oh, come on. Don't pretend you don't know about the Project. Your father died for it. Your sister was taken because of it.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: How'd you find me?

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: Heard you come here now and again. Figured you'd be needing a little drinky tonight.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: You a reporter?

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: I'm a doctor, but I think I mentioned that. OB-GYN.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Who sent you?

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: I came on my own. After reading about the bombing in Dallas.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Well, if you've got something to tell me, you've got as long as it takes me to hail a cab...

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: They're going to pin Dallas on you, Agent Mulder. But there was nothing you could've done. Nothing anyone could've done to prevent that bomb from going off. Because the truth is something you'd never have guessed; never have predicted.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: And what's that?

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: S.A.C. Darius Michaud never tried or intended to defuse the bomb.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: He just let it explode.

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: What's the question nobody's asking? Why that building? Why not the Federal Building?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: The Federal Building was too well guarded.

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: No. They put the bomb in the building across the street because it DID have federal offices. The Federal Emergency Management Agency had a provisional medical quarantine office there. Which is where the bodies were found. But that's the thing...

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: ...the thing you didn't know. That you'd never think to check.

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: Those people were already dead.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Before the bomb went off?

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: That's what I'm saying.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Michaud was a twenty-two year veteran of the bureau --

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: Michaud was a patriot. The men he's loyal to know their way around Dallas. They blew that building to hide something. Maybe something even they couldn't predict.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: You're saying they destroyed an entire building to hide the bodies of three firemen...?

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: And one little boy.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: I think you're full of shit.

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: Do you?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: I wake you?

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Why not? It's three AM.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Are you drunk, Mulder?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: I was until about an hour ago.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Is that before or after you got the idea to come here?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: What are you implying, Scully?

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: I thought you may have gotten drunk and decided to come here to talk me out of quitting.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Is that what you'd like me to do?

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Go home, Mulder. It's late.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Get dressed, Scully.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Mulder -- what are you doing?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Just get dressed. I'll explain on the way.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: We're going to the morgue.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: On whose orders?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: General McAddie is who requested our coming here. We were awakened at three AM and told to get down here immediately.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Well, call General McAddie.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: They can patch you in through the switchboard.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Hey! We don't have time to dick around here watching you demonstrate your ignorance in the chain of command. The order came direct from General McAddie. Call him. We'll conduct our business while you confirm authorization.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Why is a morgue suddenly off limits on orders of a general?

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: This is one of the firemen who died in Dallas?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: According to this tag.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: And you're looking for?

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: I can tell you that without even looking at him.  Conclusive organ failure due to proximal exposure to source and flying debris.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: This body has already been autopsied, Mulder. You can tell from the way it's been wrapped and dressed.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Does this fit the description you just read me, Scully?

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Oh my God. This man's tissue...

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: It's like jelly.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: There's some kind of cellular breakdown. It's completely edematous.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: And there's been no autopsy performed. There's no Y incision here; no internal exam.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: You're telling me the cause of death on the report is false. That this man didn't die from an explosion, or from flying debris.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: I don't know what killed this man. I'm not sure if anybody else could claim to either.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: You knew this man didn't die at the bomb site before we got here.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: I'd been told as much.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: You're saying the bombing was a cover-up. Of what?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: I don't know. But I have a hunch what you're going to find here isn't anything that can be categorized or easily referenced.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Mulder, this is going to take some time, and somebody's going to figure out soon enough we're not even supposed to be here.  I'm in serious violation of medical ethics.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: We're being blamed for these deaths. Scully, I want to know what this man died of. Don't you?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: I think this is it up here.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Is this Dr. Kurtzweil's residence?

Speaker: detective
Dialogue: You got some kind of business with him?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: I'm looking for him.

Speaker: detective
Dialogue: Looking for him for what?

Speaker: detective
Dialogue: Real nice business he's got, huh?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: detective
Dialogue: Selling naked pictures of little kids over his computer.

Speaker: detective
Dialogue: You looking for him for some other reason?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Yeah, I had an appointment for a pelvic examination.

Speaker: detective
Dialogue: You want a call if we turn up Kurtzweil?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: No. Don't bother.

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: See this bullshit...? Somebody knows I'm talking to you.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Not according to the men in blue.

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: What is it? Kiddie porn again? Sexual battery of a patient? I've had my license taken away in three states.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: They want to discredit you -- for what?

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: For what? Because I'm a dangerous man. Because I know too much about the truth.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: You mean that apocalyptic trash you write? I knew your name was familiar. I just didn't know why.

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: You know my work?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Dr. Kurtzweil, I'm not interested in bigoted ideas about race or genocide. I don't believe in the Elders of Zion, the Knights Templar, the Bilderburg Group or in a oneworld Jew run government --

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: I don't either, but it sure sells books.

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: I was right about Dallas. Wasn't I, Agent Mulder?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: I picked up the historical document of the venality and hypocrisy of the American government. The daily newspaper.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: You said the firemen and the boy were found in the temporary offices of the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Why?

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: According to the newspaper, FEMA had been called out to manage an outbreak of the Hanta virus. Are you familiar with the Hanta virus, Agent Mulder?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: It was a deadly virus spread by field mice in the Southwest U.S. several years ago.

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: And are you familiar with FEMA? What the Federal Emergency Management Agency's real power is? FEMA allows the White House to suspend constitutional government upon declaration of a national emergency. To create a non-elected government. Think about that.  What is an agency with such broad sweeping power doing managing a small viral outbreak in suburban Texas?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Are you saying it wasn't such a small outbreak?

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: I'm saying it wasn't the Hanta virus.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: What was it?

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: When we were young men in the military, your father and I were recruited for a project. They told us it was biological warfare. A virus. There were rumors about its origins.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: What killed those men?

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: What killed them I won't even write about. I tell you, they'd do more than just harass me. They have the future to protect.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: I'll know soon enough.

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: What killed those men can't be identified in simple medical terms. My god, we can't even wrap our minds around something as obvious as HIV. We have no context for what killed those men, or any appreciation of the scale in which it will be unleashed in the future. Of how it will be transmitted; of the environmental factors involved.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: A plague?

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: The plague to end all plagues, Agent Mulder. A silent weapon for a quiet war. The systematic release of an indiscriminate organism for which the men who will bring it on still have no cure. They've been working on this for fifty years. While the rest of the world was fighting gooks and commies these men have been secretly negotiating a planned Armageddon.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Negotiating with whom?

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: I think you know. The timetable has been set. It will happen on a holiday, when people are away from their homes. When our elected officials are at their resorts or out of the country. The President will declare a state of emergency, at which time all federal agencies, all government will come under the power of the Federal Emergency Management Agency. FEMA, Agent Mulder. The secret government.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: And they tell me I'm paranoid.

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: Something's gone wrong -- something unanticipated. Go back to Dallas and dig. Or you're only going to find out like the rest of the country, Agent Mulder. When it's too late.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: How can I reach you?

Speaker: kurtzweil
Dialogue: You can't.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: No calling Hawaii.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Why are you whispering?

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: I can't really talk right now.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: What did you find?

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Evidence of a massive infection.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: What kind of infection?

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Scully -- listen to me. I'm going home, then I'm booking a flight to Dallas. I'm getting you a ticket, too.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Mulder --

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: I need you there with me. I need your expertise on this. The bomb we found was meant to destroy those bodies and whatever they were infected by.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: I've got a hearing tomorrow --

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: -- I'll have you back for it, Scully. Maybe with evidence that could blow that meeting away.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: Mulder -- I can't -- I'm already way past the point of common sense here --

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Scully...? Hello...?

Speaker: field agent
Dialogue: You're looking for what amounts to a needle in a haystack. I'm afraid the explosion was so devastating there hasn't been a whole lot we've been able to put together just yet.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: I'm looking for anything out of the ordinary. Maybe something from the FEMA offices where the bodies were found.

Speaker: field agent
Dialogue: We weren't expecting to find those remains, of course. They went right off to Washington.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Was there anything in those offices that didn't go to D.C.?

Speaker: field agent
Dialogue: Some bone fragments came up in the sift this morning. We thought there'd been another fatality, but we found out FEMA had recovered them from an archeological site out of town.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: Have you examined them?

Speaker: field agent
Dialogue: No. Just fossils, far as I know.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: I'd like this person to take a look, if you don't mind.

Speaker: field agent
Dialogue: Let me just see if I can lay my hands on what you're looking for.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: You said you weren't coming?

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: I wasn't planning on it. Particularly after spending a half hour in cold storage this morning. But I got a better look at the blood and tissue samples I took from the firemen.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: What did you find?

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: The virus those men were infected with contains a protein coat I've never seen before. What it did to them it did extremely fast. And unlike the AIDS virus or any other aggressive strain, it survives very nicely outside the body.

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: How was it contracted?

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: That I don't know. But if it's through simple contact of blood to blood, and if it doesn't respond to conventional treatments, it could be a serious health threat.

Speaker: field agent
Dialogue: Like I said, these are fossils, and they weren't near the blast center, so they aren't going to tell you much.

Speaker: scully
Dialogue: May I?

Speaker: mulder
Dialogue: You said you knew the location of the archeological site where these were found.

Speaker: field agent
Dialogue: Show you right on a map.

Speaker: technician
Dialogue: It's what?

Speaker: technician
Dialogue: You see it?

Speaker: valet's voice
Dialogue: Sir -- you have a call.

Speaker: valet
Dialogue: They're in the library.

Speaker: strughold
Dialogue: We began to worry. Some of us have traveled so far, and you are the last to arrive.

Speaker: strughold
Dialogue: While we've been made to wait, we've watched surveillance tapes which have raised more concerns.

Speaker: strughold
Dialogue: We've been forced to reassess our role in Colonization by new facts of biology which have presented themselves.

Speaker: group elder
Dialogue: The virus has mutated.

Speaker: strughold
Dialogue: A new extraterrestrial biological entity.

Speaker: strughold
Dialogue: The geometry of mass infection presents certain conceptual re-evaluations for us. About our place in their Colonization.

Speaker: strughold
Dialogue: We're going to tell them what we've found. What we've learned. Turn over a body infected with the gestating organism.

Speaker: strughold
Dialogue: Let me remind you who is the new race. And who is the old.  What could be gained by withholding anything from them; By pretending to ignorance? Our knowledge may forestall their plans to step up the timetable. To start Colonization early.

Speaker: strughold
Dialogue: Cooperation is our only chance of saving ourselves.

Speaker: strughold
Dialogue: We'll continue to use them as they do us. If only to play for more time, to continue work on our vaccine.

Speaker: strughold
Dialogue: Well, without a cure for the virus, we're nothing more than digestives anyway.

Speaker: strughold
Dialogue: We've allowed this man his freedom. His books have actually helped us to facilitate plausible denial. Has he outlived his usefulness to us?

Speaker: strughold
